The rest of the show becomes EXTREMELY clique and standard, and it starts getting pretty stupid. Just watch the first season, save yourself the pain.

ARROW is one of the best series i met with.those who watching just to watch how it is going they don't like it better. but those who watch it with interest it is the best show.i gone through all the seasons and episodes strictly speaking am kind of strongly addicted to this series the plot of the series is like all the series, to save a city from criminals.actually it is a parallel story series in which two stories of our hero ARROW (Oliver Queen) runs parallel. a story of present and a story past five years.he didn't possess any superpowers like any other comic superheroes. he has some extraordinary skills learned in past in that five years. there are many connections between the past and present stories in every episode.Sometimes FLASH and other superheroes are seen in ARROW.Finally,am about to tell that i love this series,and hope you will love it if you have understood the theme of this ARROW.#################GREEN ARROW###################

Unfortunately, the writers have failed this show. Arrow used to be fantastic. I looked forward to it every week. Watched it as soon as it was out. Now I'm not sure I want to continue. Season 4 is the worst by a long shot. It's so bad that it's made me question whether I liked Arrow in the first place. Pretty sure I did. Seems like DC is really struggling to make a good show these days. Flash is still pretty good. Legends of Tomorrow is mediocre and I'm having a hard time caring about the characters. With Daredevil and Jessica Jones on the Marvel side, and Fantastic Four / Man of Steel / Batman v Superman / Supergirl on the DC side... I'm seeing just how far downhill DC has gone, while Marvel has gotten continually better (and had a good starting point).The writing in Arrow was good in s1-s3. By s4, it's just gotten cringeworthy. The whole Oliver/Felicity dynamic used to be pretty good. Now that takes about 80% of the attention of the show. It was good as a side-plot - worth about 5-10% of the plot. CW has turned it into a cringy romcom/drama. Not a superhero show.If the writers don't fix this show, I'm done, and so are countless other fans. Just look at the reactions to the last couple episodes.

OK season 1 and 2 were good to great at times, was always on my list of  must watch  for the week, but these days its  if I miss a few I don't miss anything I liked Arrow when he was sort of Batman like, skill/shadows/using knowledge to overcome greater numbers or guns, but these days thats long gone, they just walk down streets in the open, and there is a whole bunch of them on the team now.Its more like Robin Hood and his merry men, where in the past he might get away with moving quite and in shadow, this lot run all over, jump openly in front of bad guys...the list goes on.The Flash nails it, he has his team but they are the brains, very few times they will take point, 90% of the time its Barry, it works well that way, not having a whole troop follow you around (most of who pull of the same stuff as the Arrow without the training he went through....League blah blah..not all)For me they need to ditch half the team, have him do solo stuff more, odd team up, focus on Arrow and his skill, and speaking to others who watch the show, many feel the same.

I'm writing a 'spoiler free' review, so don't worry guys!!!Season 1 :Rating - 10/10S1 was full of action-packed stuff and was fun. It has lots of plot twists and the actors have done a good job in depicting their respective characters with a convincing plot. In short , Season 1 of Arrow is worth watching. Season 2 :Rating - 10/10S2 carries the same action packed sequences with a more interesting plot and it thrills the viewers. Again, the ending was convincing and I personally feel season 2 had the best villain. Again, its worth a watch.Season 3 :Rating - 8.5/10After expecting a lot from the hit series, I was disappointed after watching the 3rd season. The fight sequences became sloppy and boring. Even though, the main plot is as thrilling as ever, You can basically feel they are dragging it to finish it in the end. Last 3 episodes were fun so I have nothing to say about that. But in some episodes, I felt that the action packed series changed into a soap opera, considering the lot of crying, a character blaming him/herself for many things and some other character convincing him/her that its not their fault. It gets sloppy .... I was so disappointed after watching this season. But I couldn't stop it because I always believed that the 4th season could be better like the other seasons. Season 4Rating - 7.5/10After the disappointment from the 3rd season, I expected some new action from the fourth season. BUT, The plot is boring as hell, I wonder whether they follow the actual comic story. Every episode is boring, with too many fillers. Fight sequences - rubbish. OK , not totally rubbish, but it's bad ... I think 19 episodes released till now... There was hardly any plot in this season. Heard they are making a Season 5 for this show... Again, I hope they make it better this time... I don't believe in third chances.I recommend DC fans to watch this show. For casual viewers who want some entertaining plot, you'll do fine with the first two seasons.and for people who watch 'the flash' or 'legends of tomorrow' or both, it'll be a good watch because those three are inter-connected with the characters and the plot.

First, I want to start off this review by saying that I was a loyal DC Comics fan when I was younger so I tend to show favoritism to shows that stay true to the comics. The first 2 seasons of this show were great. Of course there were some filler episodes as is the case with shows that run a full length of 23 episodes in a season. One of the reasons why the miniseries format on Cable and streaming services are of higher quality- less episodes so the writers can be more creative and don't have to spend 23 episodes to build to a conclusion at the end of the season. But even with all those challenges, Arrow was able to be a GREAT show with all those episodes for the first 2 seasons. At the beginning of season 3, the writers lost themselves. It seems as if their creativity ran out and plot lines and episode villains were recycled. The desperation of these writers to gain back the respect of their audience has lead to departure of lead characters which surely had tarnished this show's quality forever. This show is currently on season 4 and I truly believe there is no going back. I give this show a 6 because the first 2 seasons deserved a 9 out of 10 because of the quality- the last 2 seasons deserved a 4. You can make the argument that Arrow was the show that paved the way for shows like Daredevil, The Flash, and Jessica Jones because of the quality in the first 2 seasons. That is no longer the case. What a shame...

This review does contain spoilers!!!!!!!!! It's was tolerable up until season for and that's when things get unrealistic and there were always stuff like that but it did't annoy me enough to stop watching it. But in season for episode 19 when they killed off laurel lance and she isn't coming back just made me really mad. I loved season 1 and 2 - the characters were good, the plot was decent and the series was simply very enjoyable. However, with the dawn of season 3 the story started straying from the path of superhero show and became more of a soap instead. The characters lost meaning, we saw more and more forced relationship drama, characters got killed then resurrected then killed again - the writing is a total mess now. The writers seem to focus on all the wrong things while making the story into an unredeemable trainwreck of an adaptation. Hell, actually, I can't with clean conscience call it an adaptation now, because it just borrows character names - everything else got changed too much, to the point of not being recognizable anymore. This isn't Green Arrow - this feels more like horrible fanfiction.Show needs more competent writers who don't think people watch only for  will they, won't they  - that's extremely annoying.I don't know what happened between season 2 and 3 but the drop in quality is just astounding - the plot doesn't make sense, the characters are simply ridiculous. Make it stop.

I really loved this show in season 1 and 2. The show started out as a good show in season 1, and got a lot better in season 2 with Deathstroke. Season 2 even had Deadshot and the Suicide Squad, which I loved. There were a lot of Easter eggs for comic book fans, and the show was good for both casual fans and comic book fans. Then came season 3, and things went downhill. It was not all bad. They introduced Ray Palmer (The Atom), and that was cool. But they butchered his character, making him seem like and Iron Man knockoff, giving him a super suit that can fly, and can shoot blasts of whatever they're calling it. What they should have done was give him a suit that ONLY allows him to shrink and be basically Ant-Man (comic book fans know that Ant-Man is an Atom ripoff). But instead, they made him Iron Man who can also shrink. That's number one. Number two is the League of Assassins. While I love Nyssa, using the League takes the show from a borderline Batman ripoff to full on Batman. And then there is  Olicity . Putting Oliver and Felicity together is just fan service to the casual fans who wrote fan fics for  Olicity . And then in Season 4. The big bad that may make me stop watching the show. Killing Laurel. They butchered her character by making her unlikable in season 1, and making her sister the Black Canary instead of her, is an insult to the comics. They wouldn't even give her her actual powers, instead making it into a weak choker necklace that she rarely uses. Then they kill her. Just by stabbing her with an arrow. Killing her off means they should change the name and remove the DC brand, because this is no longer a Green Arrow show. Bottom line: Watch season 1 and 2, maybe parts of season three, since it wasn't all bad. But don't watch season 4. No matter who you are. It's bad writing, and a disservice to the comics.

It really hurts giving the show such a low rating cause it doesn't do justice to the first and second season. I miss the feelings that were generated after each episode ending. You couldn't wait for the week to pass so that you can get your fix again :P. Nowadays the show is like Gossip Girl with masks. Please stop with the stupid puns and introduce real villains to the show (DCU provides endless choices), and by all means KILL FELICITY OFF...I believe I speak on behalf of all the fans when I say that this show must go back to its original darker style.I hope this change comes soon after the  promised  death of a character this season.

Arrow is a very good show initially. Sure the acting is not always great, and a few of the characters are annoying, but until about mid 2nd-season this is very entertaining and has great character development. But thereafter... oh my... If you want a good show, stop watching after the 2nd season. If you, on the other hand, want to see pretty much every character on the show running around with a bow and fighting bad guys after 2 weeks of training without getting shot every 2sec, then you might like the rest as well. In this show you, as a woman, can go to the gym and practice boxing for a few weeks and then you are ready to fight grown men by the dozen. And this is not the only premise which is ridiculous to say the least. The show still produce one or two episodes which are good, also after season two, but in general the show becomes so boring and so predictable and get so many plot-holes it is hard to see its the same show. Only a few guest appearances by The Flash and a few scenes here and there keep the spirit up. Also on this show they cannot die. Someone get a sword through their chest? Well throw them into this puddle of water and whamowhamo they are beating up bad guys again. Someone explodes? No worries! Its all fine. Stabbed to death in prison? Pfff, thats nothing, just get up and shake it off... In the beginning of the show it was exciting and although you sort of know the heroes will pull through, it is never a certain, they even lose once in a while. But keep watching and you suddenly know that even a dull pointless character that really should have died in prison, actually survives and comes back later.I still have some hope for Arrow. It can still turn things around, but if not I really hope the next season is the last because the show has been dying slowly for a couple of years now. Personally I love the basic gang from season 1 plus the Thea Queen character, the rest should just die in some horrible attack which would rejuvenate the show, bring some excitement back and give us a feel of dread again. Oh, and Oliver should stop dreaming and flashing back to that stupid island by now. Every single episode, even as the show goes on, he flashes back to his Robinson Crusoe days. Stop it please!

Well I like this series Arrow.its so funny,Its full of good actors and the plot is alright.Anyways,there's something I hate about this series.I mean,I'm with the person I know(e.g.Oliver Queen,I know him,he's my friend.I look at his face(e.g facial hair, and lips everyday)but when he's wearing a hood,which only covers his forehead,I won't be able to know/see who he is.He has the same facial hair,but I won't see that he's Oliver Queen.Again,I have a daughter(Laurel),I know her because I look at her face(e.g eyes) everyday but when she wearing a mask which does not cover anything at all,I won't be able to see and/or know that that is my daughter I'm talking to.That's so stupid.I was going give this series a rating of 10/10,but I'm giving it a 5 because I subtracted a 5 from 10 because of what I wrote above.So if you thinking of watching.Don't.But if you got nothing else to watch,watch Arrow.The series is funny but kinda stupid.

ARROW = AWESOME.This isn't about a superhero this is about a hero which means that he does not have any super powers like many others have . This can be seen by an adult or a teen . There are many twists and suspense s .Stephan Amell had done great stunts .This TV series is and action packed adventure one . And once again ARROW = AWESOME. Accordin to me this is the best TV Series I have ever seen. John Barrowman have also given excellent performance. Emily Bett Rickards ,without any doubt have also performed well.This is indeed an excellent TV Series for a newbie or a pro.Susanna Thompson is also given some amazing performance.

After Smallville I approached Arrow with great caution. However this turned out to be a very all around TV series, much more evolved than Smallville in terms of quality of the production. The hero is not perfect, he learns and develops. Flashbacks are much more than a glimpse of past, they keep you wondering and the way writers tie past and present events is masterful. Stephen Amell is not only a great action star but his mimics and tone of his voice really gets to you. You can clearly see the difference of his tone when he is the  Arrow  and when he was the kid before the island. Even the main villains like Slade Wilson, Malcom Meryln and Ra'as are quite likable characters. The only irritating part in this series is Katie Cassidy's performance on Laurel. I'm not sure if the writers are deliberately portraying her like this but I'm very happy that Oliver Queen was not stuck with her as a lover for the rest of the series.

I have been just watching some episodes from season 3. The obtrusively repeated  torture is necessary  formula makes one ask, weather the CIA is cosponsoring the series. The repeated  we are here to keep the city save from terrorism  and  torture is a necessary evil to do just that  leaves a foul taste in ones mouth. Considering it comes from a country which terrorizes the world with war while financing and training the terrorists they are claiming to fight as a pretext to invade oil rich countries, this series is a picture book of propaganda. The characters are a bit hollow too and the hero is - of course - your good neighborhood billionaire of the 0.001 percent. While real billionaires have gazillion of lobbyists doing their biding and politicians waiting in the lobby for there paycheck, this peculiar billionaire is playing with bow and arrows and is doing the torturing without CIA aid all by himself. Nice pictures for dumbed down though in the Nighted States.

I would love this show, except that it regularly gives a dose of incredibly bad  moral  lessons. The latest came with episode 15 of season 4. Felicity finds out that Oliver has a son from a previous relationship, something he didn't tell her because the birth mother demanded that he keep it a secret for everyone else, to shelter the child (William) from Oliver's tumultuous life. Oliver's been through hell and back to prove himself to his friend and his fiancée, and still that's not enough - she can't  marry  him. It's all Oliver's fault. He's the  bad  guy and everyone's expected to attain to a standard of perfection, that of course nobody in the show lives up to. Ridiculous. And the degree of Felicity's selfishness in all things Oliver is really quite obscene and disgusting.Well, one less show to watch. Too much with the BS!

With the recent release of season 4, I was going in hoping for some great new incite into the character Arrow.The first 3 seasons were surprisingly good and I loved the back story showing how he became 'The Green Arrow'.Alas it's starting to take a dive for the worse. Firstly the whole Felicity relationship/trust and all that nonsense is really wearing thin and getting in the way of what could be a far better story. PLEASE throw it out. At least her misfortune made for an interesting twist as the character was making me want to throw something through the screen.Secondly the flash back scenes are not tying in well with the episodes and are becoming more of a random filler than integral parts of the main story.Thirdly, the fight scenes are becoming boring. They seem so over staged and ridiculous there's almost no point in having them. I was overjoyed that the league was dissolved as the whole angry daughter of Ryule was becoming monotonous.Here's hoping Season 5 can get back to the ground work days of Seasons 1 and 2. Those really had me getting into the character. Now I think the problem is there focusing to heavily on the characters around our main hero and this is detracting from the core element of the show.Also, I know many will not like this but they need to have characters die and stay dead. Bringing them back is getting cheesy. It's not exactly going to be shocking if a character dies anymore as there's a good chance they will miraculously just re-appear in a future episode.Think 'Game Of Thrones'. The deaths of characters you like shock you and they don't come back which adds to the story.Essentially any believability with realism has been thrown out the window for a terrible Cosplay like inferior imitation. The whole, make all the women right all the time and the guy is just a person who makes all the mistakes really gets on my nerves and is anti-equalitarian. It's sexist against men and doesn't make for smart drama at all.To conclude I'm giving the overall series so far a 6 where as until Season 4 it would have scored a 9. This mirror's Episodes 1,2 and 3 of the Star Wars movies. Essentially I wish they had never made Season 4 of Arrow, it's ruined a great series.Holding hope for Season 5 but if it's got more of the same, where in for a forgettable show.

I absolutely love everything about this show. This show has inspired me to be an actor and how Stephen Amell portrays oliver queen, I think is one of the most outstanding performances off all acting. My dream is to one day be apart of the DC universe.I really can not say enough how much bringing Diggle into the arrow as the leader/voice of reason is truly amazing. The storyline for all seasons so far has been fantastic (if you really concentrate and focus on them and the flash backs). The way this one show has also made two more shows because of there success explains why you need to watch it. The flash and legends of tomorrow have been absolutely fundamental as well. I can not wait too see if they are planning on bringing Batman, Night wing, Aqua man, and whoever else.

I really liked the first season of Arrow. It was a dark show about  superheroes  wandering the street and delivering justice. It was something that Smallville could not be. Grounded, believable. Had some of the soap opera feel, but it was toned down to an acceptable level. After the first season many of the better parts including the high body count started to retreat into the background. I always held Flash to a lower standard due to its more  One Tree Hill  approach to the story, but ultimately as of the time of my writing Arrow hit the all-time low for me, as I am now struggling to watch it while I have a decent time with the latest episodes of the speedster. Unfortunately, I do not think Flash got smarter or better, it is just the fact that it is consistent, I always get the stuff that I expect. I have to look away when those cheesy moments come up. In the fourth season of Arrow they introduced supernatural elements to the story. Seems like they needed something like meta-humans to stay attractive. While I am mostly settled with the presence of Damian Darhk, I cannot fathom the fact that they are resurrecting long dead people. Resurrected story lines are almost as ridiculous as the fetish to make everyone related to the main characters meta-human, a criminal or just simply not normal. I understand that these shows are for young adults basically, but I still cannot believe that something should be this much predictable and stupid. Also, the new island stuff is laughable, it does not add anything valuable or new. And of course they needed to write the now canceled Constantine into the show.

I have tried and tried to love this show, as I was a long time DC fan, but boy does the writing leave a lot to be desired. Great cast, I don't blame them. The star is impressive, super beefcakey for the girls I guess, really impressive climbing pull ups... the overview is good... vigilante story turning a corner. Silly is the only word I can use to describe the direction that it did turn down. Groups attacking a city to that degree and the National Guard doesn't get a chance to help. Surely a few costumed archers can save the day though. Earthquake machines, secret islands, the Lazarus pit seems the least of the oddities, but sure, it can bring life to the dead with only minor PTSD.The recent fight scene with Raz Al Gul was so incredibly disappointing and unrealistic, I nearly barfed. I far more enjoyed the batman cartoon's version of the league of assassins, who, initially were more than any one of our Arrow heroes could deal with, but now they seem to be able to knock them down like bowling pins.I know that this stuff is fantasy, but silly is what it's turning out as. As in the Flash, the actors are NOT the problem, the writers are just sub-par. The show is feeling far too formulaic, and the actions of most of the characters are just unrealistic.  if you let me out of this prison cell, I'll give you this rock I'm holding in my hand through the bars .Please try to write something slightly not lame... I really want to enjoy the DC universe as much as I am Marvel.

This is not a bad series but not the best either. I gave it 5 stars for the simple reason of it not being original, trying to turn Green Arrow into more like Batman by using Batman's arch villains and the teen titans arch villains, and trying to make Oliver Queen more brooding like Bruce Wayne. Plus using one of the plot lines from Batman's history and using it for Green Arrow's was about sickening for me. Check out the end of season 3.Then there is flash back scenes that happen like every few minutes tends to be annoying. The multiple girl friend drama and the other excess drama tended to be writers block and ended up being filler to make the episode last for the entire duration.Now since I got that off my chest, if you know nothing about the comics then you might enjoy the series if you can get past the excess drama and half of the episodes being flashbacks.

Another Comic Book Superhero show that gets high ratings because... its a comic book superhero. People are easily entertained, and by the 8+ stars this show had on IMDb there's no reason for Hollywood to change a thing. You can throw any piece of superhero garbage out there and people love it. I honestly believe if you made a comic book called The Hot Dog people would watch it.The Hot Dog is about a guy (Timmy Frankfurter) who works in a meat processing plant. The cooperate CEO's are having the lab work on a new meat preservative that the FDA is unaware of and has not been tested, but could make the company hugely more profitable. They accidentally leave some of the new preservative laying around and Timmy is accidentally injected. The preservative disfigures him, resembling a walking, talking wiener, but in turn, makes Timmy preserved himself, rendering him impervious to anything but fire. The Hot Dog shoots a relish like substance from his nose that sticks to anything it touches, thwarting any oncoming attack. Or he blows an onion-like gas out of his ears that burns peoples eyes, basically incapacitating them....Now, I understand that makeup and CGI will have to work on a Man/Hot Dog with ears and a nose, but I'm telling you people would watch it. Just put in a couple outlandish-looking weapons, 2 or three big explosions each episode, and finally (of course) 2 hot girls making out and I guarantee 3/4 of the reviewers would give it 8-10 stars. They'd write crappy reviews like,  Original. I was entertained and strangely hungry throughout the entire show.  or,  I felt for the Hot Dog and his inner battles. It reminded me of my battles choosing between ketchup and mustard...  I once heard someone say that people will applaud anything, and it is so true. People are entertained because they think they were supposed to be entertained... People, it is okay to actually think.BTW, If anyone wants to by the rights to The Hot Dog, please contact my agent.So, to my long awaited Arrow review.... It sucks!

Arrow is successfully disappointing in every aspect that I could think of: (big spoiler alert!!! )1.Directing- The scenes are poorly directed. Lets start from the poor performance of the characters which I believe could have done better with another director. For example Oliver (the Arrow) is believed to be dead for 5 years, when he comes back home from the dead he get a soft hug from his sister (Really??? a hug ??? you could think he went on a bushiness trip and came back), don't get me wrong I'm not looking for much emotions in this series but this is a poor understanding of the situation. Other then the performance the scenes are just not professionally filmed! another strong example is at one of the scenes Oliver is talking with his mother not arguing of fighting but using cold sentences to each other) and all of a sudden his sister ,which observed them from far distance, claim that they had a fight (OK maybe she can read their lips). there are so many scenes that I can give you but you got the point and I should continue to the next thing. Second thing which keeps going all the time is that the Arrow is using arrows and his enemies using guns,automatic weapons and they keep missing the target.As far as I can tell the arrow doesn't have a super dodge ability, and it seemed too lame that police officers, S.W.A.T teams and special forces soldier all miss the Arrow and even the camera angle doesn't let you thing that there is a far distance between them (oh God this is insulting). Third thing is that many time the Arrow is hunting some evil guy and they seem to miraculously disappear right in front of him!! (OK maybe he is not that a sharp hero).2.Plot development- OK this even worse the the poor directing. for a whole season Oliver is murdering people who allegedly corrupted the city.He is the judge and the executioner (Ok this will change as the series goes). but what really bothers me is that most of the characters around the Arrow doesn't seem to worry about the killing spree .Only 2 characters does, and only at a very late part of the series. Another thing is that there are 3-4 enemies that keep come back at the first and second season. I love when a character is suddenly comes back to the series but this is happening too many time!! with the same characters !! come on the DC universe has plenty of villains, use them! Another is that the Arrow identity isn't kept as secret as you expect, at some point everyone knows who is the Arrow except new villains. One last thing that shows again how the plot is poorly developed is that the characters had done some terrible things one to another (cheating, lying, kidnapping,drugging, murdering ) but they somehow in an unreasonable way forgive each other or even worse - help each other (!?!?). I could keep on criticizing this series and keep on with the spoilers (the big one is at middle of season 3 which I decided not to mention here) but if you read this far you probably make up your mind already so Ill save you from more spoilers/criticizing .2 good things I have to say about the Arrow (the reason why I rate it 3/10 and not 1/10) 1.The connection to the DC comic world by joining interesting character to the series (especially joining forces with another TV series. A step I think had never been seen before on the screen). but this happened too late I suppose to save this poor series. you probably ask yourself why I keep watching this series, only to understand another good, amazing, thrilling and Flashing series. 2. Villains that are though enough to beat down the arrow - this is comes only at the middle of season 2 and season 3 but it surely add a lot to the emptiness of this series . and of course the Arrow ridiculously defeat them somehow thanks to the director.In a sentence - this series could have been much greater, but it managed to be a disaster (i.e the Arrow character at Smallville was way much better). this is a real insult to your intelligence. think twice before staring to watch this big disappointment.

A lot of the reviews for the show say that Arrow isn't any good because it's repetitive, unoriginal, poorly-scripted, etc., and I completely disagree. THIS SHOW IS ABOUT HOW OLIVER QUEEN BECOMES THE GREEN ARROW. It's meant to be an origins story, so I agree when people say the characters (especially Oliver) make the same mistakes more than once, but it's supposed to be that way. This show is meant to portray how Oliver Queen went from being consumed by darkness (as Arrow) to being a symbol of hope for Star City (as Green Arrow). Oliver has a really messed up background, and this story tries to explain how he overcame his definite trust issues and overbearing protectiveness to BECOME A HERO. I never read the comics or anything like that, but my main reason for loving this show is because of the character evolution. It's crazy to watch the current season and go back to watch the first episodes of season 1 because the show is so incredibly different now. Oliver has gone from being a murderer to becoming a hero, and that means the tone of the show has changed entirely. Something else you have to remember when watching this show is that it's television. Every show (especially the ones on the cw) needs drama to survive. You have to keep the show interesting, and the characters have to be doing something new every season, or it'll get stale. So far, the writers have done a pretty good job at this. They do recycle old material ever now and then, but they've done an okay job so far. I will admit that the first couple seasons had a lot of filler episodes, but so far in season 4, there haven't been many (if any at all) that didn't directly go back to main big bad of the season. There have been a couple that were meant to set up the new show Legends of Tomorrow that I could have lived without though.I will agree with other viewers when they say the show can be inconsistent because there are a couple of things that tend to get annoying. Like Laurel Lance. The character doesn't serve any purpose that someone else can't fill, and I'm still trying to figure out how she got so good at fighting within like 5 episodes. And is she even a lawyer anymore? Things like this are why I couldn't give the show all 10 stars. All in all, though, Arrow is one of my favorites, and I'll continue to watch it until the series finale.

If you want to watch something entertaining, captivating and exciting then you must watch this. But keep in mind this show does not fully satisfy the most solid-reasoning demanding minds because there are events lacking logical explanations that make this show somewhat inconsistent.If it was not for these flaws, I would admire this show more, but even so this is worth the opportunity to be watched for one or two episodes to make your own opinion.The acting is good, not great but delivers what is supposed to. However, the actresses involved in fights should be more fit if we are expected to give more credibility.Most of the fighting moves are better than for example Daredevil (which is quite great overall) but there are still some moves that need to be practiced more.Production is OK for the budget but I would like to see more realistic explosions not those Power-Rangers-like sparks.I want to recognize and thank the writers and everybody involved in this show because I think it is not easy to entertain us watchers for 4 seasons so far and have good ratings.

In season one the Arrow is just a murderer, plain and simple. The acting is bad, the characters are bad and unrealistic, it's pretty much a soap opera.He has an  enlightenment  by the end of S01 for no apparent reason (much like Ben Affleck in daredevil) so at least that part gets better by season two, since he stops murdering people, but almost nothing else changes. The acting is still cringeworthy, the characters are still pulled straight out of Santa Barbara. I don't know why I stuck with the show until halfway through season 3, but I did and it doesn't get any better.The action is fun I guess so the show has going for it but other than that, it's really no good (it's certainly not an 8.1 in my book).

Entertaining at first simply because we all want to know what happened on the island and how he managed to survive but they show us slowly, teasing with bits and pieces of the past that will either intrigue you or cause you to give up on knowing. I understand that it's part of the  mystery , not revealing the entire 5 years of his disappearance but it's starting to feel as if they are keeping us in the dark so they can use the past to introduce whatever crazy plot or storyline at any given time.There's action and entertainment I will admit but later it gets so repetitive that you will be able to guess the outcome before it happens. Also, there's the irony of him always  lying to protect  his loved ones in which , the lies cause more damage than the actual truth. Half of the bad things that happened wouldn't have had he just revealed his identity. Entertaining on a Sunday with no cable

Major Spoilers Ahead!Only up to the 2nd season...so far 1/4 of the show is about childish tantrums and drama worthy of a soap opera. At least the whining was covered by both sexes in the first season, but with the death of the stooge Tommy (good riddance) most of the whining comes from the female characters (except Sara). Moira's slightly condescending reaction to her daughter professing love ( I love Roy ) summarizes the feelings about the inane subplots: Roy who? I said  stfu Thea  out loud at least once every episode in the second season.The best part of the show is the flashback plot that explains Oliver's time on the island. The villains aren't always a hit (The Count), but most of them are portrayed well enough both in writing and acting.

i love this show so much season 3 was my personal favorite because of the story lines but all 4 are amazing. If you are looking for a good action, adventive, drama, sci-fi show then 'Arrow' is the show for you,also if you like 'Arrow' then you should watch 'The Flash' because they cross over and have good story lines. In the show there is an amazing romance between 'Oliver' and 'Felicity' there ship name is 'Olicity' i think they are an amazing couple and have shipped them since the beginning of the shoe when Felicity was first introduced. 'Roy' and 'Thea' also have an amazing relation ship and both join Oliver's team to help fight 'Slade Wilson' and 'Deathstokes' 'Mirakuru' soldiers.

1. Okay, I'm a guy that LOVES to sleep around, but the characters in this show sleep around so much it makes the girls look like total sluts. Every time Thea or Felicity or Laurel gets to meet a new character introduced into the show, they are asked out on a date and end the date humping2. So much inconsistency. At one point, two characters are best of friends / family and nothing on earth can break that bond, then next minute they're enemies. Seriously, I think the writers are 5 year olds on crack to write a show like this.3. EVERYONE becomes a super hero. The main character's lover, ex- lover, sister, hell even the next door neighbor's dog becomes a super hero (okay that last one's a joke but seriously...) Is it really that easy to become a semi-invincible god like fighter? And what is up with all the female fighters? I mean I'm not sexist or anything but please at least choose women who can do the choreography right. When Laurel Lance fights... it is... absurd to say the least. You can literally see her doing the  girly girl swing  with her punches. If they chose Ronda Rousey to do the action scenes, at LEAST the fights would be memorable, but the producers messed that up too.4. In summary, this is the most absurd, bad action, bad acting, stupidly put storyline TV show I've EVER watched, and I'ved watched TV for over 36 years, in 8 different countries.

Fantastic show. I always look for solid character development in every movie or TV show regardless of genre and this show definitely brings it. The action scenes are great, don't get me wrong and I am sure that a majority of the audience is in it for those scenes. And the story line is likewise fantastic. However, what really hooks me is the constant traits of friendship and sacrifice that is prevalent in the show. Each member of the team would offer themselves as a sacrifice for one another time and time again. Even in Season 3 when all hope seems lost, Oliver is still trying to save his friends lives in exchange for his own life. Over all, I love the show.

This show is amazing! The actors are great, a lot of great scenes, a lot of people were q tiny bit disappointed by the 3rd season (i am not one of them) but clearly they are not anymore thanks to this amazing 4th season! I love the story, the crossovers, the fight scenes, keep up the good work! Every time I watch an episode i cannot wait for the next week to watch the next one. I love Arrow, Stephen Amell is one of my top idols with his acting, him being a hero on TV and in real life (F*ck Cancer) and his amazingly perfect body...I wish I can meat you one day. I also cannot wait to watch TMNT 2! Please keep Arrow going for as many seasons as you can. *SPOILER ALERT* Try to shoot scenes that only involve OTA (Original Team Arrow) more often just like you did in an episode in season 4 that i adored!Thank you!

I really do not understand how this show has an 8.1 average. Sometimes it is so difficult to fathom how the writers came up with such a clichéd TV series. Now don't get me wrong, I am all about clichés and cheesy dialogues but this show has taken all of those aspects to a whole new level with an extra strong added ingredient of  stupid .For example, Sara Lance comes back to Starling City, and just because she wears a tiny eye mask, her own sister cannot tell it's her? And what's with the cheesy  Mirakuru ? It would have sounded much less cheesier if they had called it  The miracle drug  or something like that.Another example, is when Thea Queen get's kidnapped by Slade. If you get  KIDNAPPED , you'd be fearing for your life. I mean did Thea know that Slade was not going to kill her when she was first abducted? She would have been quaking in her boots and traumatized, to say the LEAST. Yet when she is let go, the only thing she can dwell on is the fact that Oliver didn't tell her the truth about her father? Really? Wouldn't she just be happy that she  STILL HAS HER OWN LIFE ?Things like this keep bothering the hell out of me, and the ONLY reason I watch this show (albeit while biting down on my tongue), is because I want to know how the story fits with The Flash, and all the good TV shows have been watched already.If you don't care about whether a TV show makes sense, or care about storyline, or decent action, then go ahead and watch it, but for me... I'm awestruck at how stupid a show they can make.Some GOOD TV shows I can recommend:- Person of Interest- Da Vinci's Demons- The Blacklist- The Flash

I actually enjoyed the first season of this show. I can suspend disbelief for any fantasy that is reasonable( zombies in Walking Dead that can be killed just with a spike to the brain? No problem). I even could overlook the unlikely fact that Oliver becomes a world champion ninja warrior on the island. But then came the real insult to our intelligence. We are expected to believe that his skinny kid sister (Thea) and even skinnier ex girlfriend (Laurel) can become amazing ninja superheroes with just a few months of training sessions. Suddenly they can beat most beafy badass men in a fight??? WTF???? Why is no one talking about this???Fail That's when you lost me. Sorry

Why do you just have to revolve story around silly natters of relation among the lead roles instead of a hero doing at least a bit productive.It's just a silky drama for people to watch and cry until no reason has left in them.No thrill or action just a story of a man of who is rotating among his friends and family problems and has no time for good action.

I somehow endured 3 seasons of this, just because I had nothing to watch. It's not even THAT bad if you think about main story line, just a relaxing show, everything is pretty mediocre, but the main problem here is... Fillers. 23 episodes each season, about 7-8 of them are actually tied to the main story line, rest of the episodes they're dealing with maniacs, serial killers, robbers, drug dealers etc. It's totally pointless, cause you always know who will win and you always know that no one from the  good guys  will be seriously hurt/die in the process. Later it gets even worse - they're re-using same filler characters, they magically resurrecting, escaping from prison and other bs, but at least you're aware right at the start of an episode that it's going to be a lousy filler yet again.Really don't understand why they need to make 23 episodes each season when most of them filled with stuff like I described above. It's really painful to watch and kills any amount of hype so that you don't even care about main story anymore.

If you like it, well it's just fine. But I really don't and I won't see the 4th season when it'll be aired in France next summer ! And please, the acting !!! Come on ! Start acting, not taking poses for the cameras ! I think why the producers chose Amell is only for his good looks. Not because he's a good actor... And the series... Season after season, we always have the same scripts coming from the first season's episodes ! Arrow wins, Arrow loses... He wins, he looses... He wins, he loooses... Someone died ! He wins, he looooses... He wins, he loooooses... He wins, he looooooses... Oops, another one died ! He wins, he loooooooses... He wins, he looooooooses... He wins, he loooooooooses... He wins, he... OH my Goash : I see Dead People !!! OK, Arrow is still alive... But for me, this TV-Series is already dead.Arrow ? Never more for me !

I have always been a huge fan of comic book superheros. The whole cast for The Arrow, is honestly perfect! I haven't really have had any disappointments with the show. Although DC Comics definitely isn't beating Marvel in the movie industry, it has a foothold in television. While DC Comics currently has  Arrow ,  The Flash ,  Gotham , and now  Supergirl , Marvel only has a few kids' channel shows, along with the non-superhero  Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.  and  Agent Carter . Suffice it to say,  Arrow  is definitely the best superhero TV show ever. Once a Batman show comes along, that may change, but for now  Arrow  is a perfect show to sit down and binge-watch.Oliver Queen is stranded on an island for five years, and has been presumed dead along with his father. His father is dead, but he has survived, and his return to Starling City changes the city forever. He has turned from carefree spoiled brat to a buff dude with wicked bow-wielding abilities. He puts a green cloak on with a hood that hides most of his face, puts on some face paint and goes out at night ridding the city of one-percenters.  You have failed this city,  he growls before either sticking an arrow in them or having mercy on them and stuffing them in jail instead. He's not a loner for long, recruiting Oliver Queen's bodyguard, John Diggle, to help him out. Diggle is reluctant at first to be an accomplice of a vigilante. He believes that Oliver doesn't have the right, and of course he's right, but somehow Oliver convinces him anyway. Felicity Smoak also eventually comes along to help Oliver hack and dig through secret government databases...just like a babbling version of Oracle.Oliver Queen has more problems to deal with, than just the vigilante-related problems. His family has had quite a shock, a pleasant one, but a shock nonetheless at his return. Everyone is unbearably curious as to what happened to him on the island, but he is not quite ready to share, and will likely never be. Through flashbacks his past is slowly revealed to the audience; he wasn't alone on that island, and he was tortured...quite a lot happened. He even meets up with Slade Wilson, and becomes close allies with him as they try to escape the island together.Throughout Season 1 lots of familiar villains show up, and the excitement increases. Arrow has yet to grow into the Green Arrow, and by the end of Season 1 he has completely changed. Arrow: Season 1 is a classic example of what a TV series should look like.86/100

Possibly contains spoilers if anyone else started watching this as late as I did: I just started watching this, got about half-way through the first season, but I won't be finishing it. As many others have stated, it's like watching a soap opera. Oh my, the wah-wah drama! The best friend who hasn't grown up one iota in the last five years, still wants to party like they did in college. (But didn't the show state that Oliver dropped out of every college he attended?) But he is going to manage Oliver's club, even though, apparently, no one actually learned anything, but we are to believe they know how to run businesses.Then you have the ex-girlfriend who's sleeping with the bestie but wants the cheating back-from-the-grave ex. This same damsel-in- constant-distress who says she can take care of herself and her job, until she can't, which seems to be every time; she just can't seem to get out or her own way. (BTW, just how did this girl, her sister, the friend-with-benefits who is now a cop, etc., get into the billionaire- boys-club in the first place? I never read the comics so I would really like to know.) Then you have her father, who also can't get out of his own way because he must get that vigilante. Gets a tip of a major crime and all he can focus on is getting that vigilante.The show could have had promise with better writers and directors. I give the actors a break as they are playing the scenes as written and directed. I think they all could have done better if they had a better crew behind the camera.

OK when I first started watching this show I thought it would be worth following. And it was for a while but this show, like The Flash has gone so far above imaginative reality I just can't take it anymore. And oh by the way, we are now in the 4th season, it's about time to stop doing the stupid flashback scenes. This show has become one for a young preteen audience and the mentally challenged. And IMDb some shows just are not worth 10 lines in a review. This is one of them. Lighten up a little.

I bought the first 2 seasons of Arrow before watching it, and boy am I glad that I started before I bought anymore. I never read the comic books, so I was going into this show with no real idea of who the Green Arrow was. And I must say it didn't leave a good impression of him on me. The plot isn't well developed. Each episode has a conflict introduction at the beginning and a resolution at the end. It really takes away from the feel of it as a show, with most conflicts not carrying over into the next few episodes. If your going to hold a big angry grudge then hold it for longer than 45 minutes, especially considering the characters reactions are so overdone when they begin a grudge and when they end it. The general plot is pretty generic for a superhero show, which is fine, but I feel like it could have been so much deeper still.The characters themselves aren't great. The actors really aren't anything special, which doesn't help in selling the characters. They have a handful of emotional breakdowns in every episode, and it gets stale really, really fast. It just becomes recycled scenes, and it feels unoriginal and repetitive. And overall the characters can be pretty dumb and oftentimes feel this way thanks to these emotional breakdowns. You could say that they're just emotional people, but considering the fact that EVERYONE is like this, it makes the cast feel much less diverse and interesting. Not only that, but they are oftentimes just dumb people. Not just a few characters, the majority of them make lots of really dumb decisions all the time where the safer and easier resolution is blatantly obvious.  Look I understand that this is a superhero show but you don't have to take the most risky path Oliver because chances are you'll get shot again. The pilot and first episode of season 2 were some of the worst episodes I've ever seen in any TV show. If I had watched the pilot on TV and hadn't bought the first two seasons I definitely would not have continued. I did like that the show focuses more on the characters than fighting bad guys. Unfortunately, the characters weren't done that well to begin with, so the show was lacking in this case. The last 4-5 episodes of both seasons were often much better than the rest of the season, which provided enough reason to continue with the series after season 1 (mostly with the hopes that it'd get better). I don't plan on going past season 2, but it was nice to see that the show made it's last stand of the season a good one. The best part of the show in my opinion were the flashbacks. Often the best episodes were ones where flashbacks were frequent and clips from them were longer than 10 seconds. Overall Arrow just wasn't that great. The excess of emotional breakdowns got annoying and took away from the characters, the structure of each episode, and the shallow plot combined made it difficult to get through at times. I found that the show could very inconsistent at times, with one thing being a problem at one point but then that problem disappearing because it was easier film-wise to just not address it ever again. However, it makes up in some way due to the flashbacks and improvements at the end of each season. Unfortunately, the ending wasn't enough to keep me going for another season of forced drama and poor story-telling. Sure, it had it's good points, but in the end the show just wasn't anything special.

There wasn't a zero so I had to give a 1.It is painful to sit through muscle flaunting, lip gloss, skinny designer clothed, animated puppet photography which passes for acting in a show geared to replace 90210 and suchlike.Most obvious and no matter how hard they try, they just CAN'T explain this one away - how does an arrow out gun a....gun? Nice try but ...do you really think we are that STUPID???Why America? WHY???????To sell more c**p and manufactured, unrealistic ideas about life and it's problems to the impressionable? I know a lot of people are currently reviewing the entire show of this to be some ridiculous TV show that has some no interest of anyone over the age of 12, but, I'm 25 and due to the fact that a majority of all TV shows now on-air currently are using DC Universe and Marvel I EXCEPTED change from the Comic Books to the TV show. Everyone is in a high-horse due to this chance, but IT has to be different to fit, because a comic book is only a 5 minute read which is only a 1-minute TV show.The acting in this is fine, you don't have to be a person which has some stupid hypocritical state to be bother by it. If there is anything in this TV show that has to bother you, like it has bothered me is the actions scenes that do not reflect other scenes that have happened.Such as broken glass in a van or the bodies that fall to the ground in one position and end up different in the next scene.If you're looking for a DC comic TV show, then you're safe to watch this without anything going bad for you. If you've read the comics you'll find some familiarity but not all. Same goes for The Flash.

This series is so overrated , it crap , s**t p**p , so here my review I want to love Arrow, I really do.Green Arrow has always been one of my favorite DC heroes, and I'm thrilled that he's got his own very successful TV show which, to be fair, is a damn sight better than it might have been. But that doesn't mean that it's as good as it should be.My relationship with the show has run hot and cold. I watched the first seven episodes and quit. Later, during the second season, several friends recommended I give it another try, reassuring me it had gotten a lot better, so I went back and watched everything from the point I'd stopped. And I was glad I did, because it was getting better, and by the end of second season, it was pretty great. I went into the third season excited to see what the show's creators would do next, and then things got painful.Eleven episodes in, basically halfway through the season, I quit again. That was several weeks ago, and this week I decided to give it another chance to get better again, and I've now watched up through the season's thirteenth episode,  Canaries.  And it's still not must-see TV.Before getting into what's wrong with the show, I want to mention some things that are right about it<U+0085>

*SPOILER*... Here is the dialogue from every Arrow episode ever written :   you are wrong   ,   you were wright  ,  no you stay here   ,  you were correct but also wrong   ,   are you OK ?  ,   are you OK  and especially   I'm sorry   ,  are you OK ?   <U+0085> sounds captivating doesn't it ?Biggest issue out of the way : if one decides to make a superhero series and divide every 45 minute episode in 35 minutes of dialogue and 10 minutes of actual action ; wouldn't it be an inspired idea to make the dialogue <U+0085> good ? ALL of them go trough the same thing every time and they never ever learn from their mistakes , it's so frustrating . It's like you're in a badly written reboot of Groundhog day . More good writing : occasionally they have a good story arc going yet every time they choose to sacrifice it in order to keep a cliffhanger vibe going <U+0085> that's marketing , not writing . When they try to entertain a longer story , they always bury it for a while to maintain their   every week a new villain   thing and guess what : KEEP THE CLIFFHANGER GOING !!! When the end of the season is close by , the sword of Damocles hangs above all . Enter new season , that sword turned out to be a pin our hero forgot to take out of his new shirt ... you know , lazy writing .

*WARNING CONTAINS HEAVY SPOILERS* As of today I've only watched the first two seasons, but I wanted to review this show already, just because it's so great. This is a show about what would really happen if someone put on a costume and started fighting crime. And two seasons later we're all loving it. Let's start with the pros. The cast is all really good. Willa Holland as Thea Queen is especially good, as is Manu Bennet as Slade Wilson, aka Deathstroke. That's not to discredit the others, they're all good as well, I just can't list each one individually because a) I don't know their names and b) if I did, we'd be here all day. Something else I like about the show is how much it emulates the comics. We have standard tropes of the comic books as well as subtle references, and the occasional poke at the source material. Aside from Flash, no superhero show has ever captured the comics this well, and this show takes everything good about comics, and everything good about regular drama/crime shows, and merges it together to make what just might be my favorite show. I also like that it doesn't degenerate into cartoony silliness, and keeps the entire thing grounded in reality, and takes the whole thing seriously. That being said though, I loved that they later introduced some actual super-powers, Slade, Roy, etc. I think it would've been interesting if Roy had kept his powers, and he was forced to control them, I think that would've been very interesting. But here's something strange, people I know did not like the inclusion of super-powers, so... am I alone on this, or what? Let's talk about the finales some, and a couple other episodes that stand out. I liked the ending of season 1 because you had a really great wrap up to everything, a final duel with the villain that had a great climax, and a really tragic moment when Tommy dies and the Glades are destroyed. It's interesting seeing the bad guys kind of winning. The finale to season 2 on the other hand was more or less a mixed bag for me. Let me put it this way: when it was the personal fight between Oliver and Slade, that was good. When it was armies of super-soldiers just getting wiped out by the League of assassins, I was actually kind of bored. They diminished the threat of the soldiers to the point where you didn't feel any danger. The other episode I wanted to talk about was City of Blood, which follows Moira Queen's death, in this episode, Oliver is going to turn himself in to Slade to save the rest of his loved ones. They handled that really well, with how you don't see Oliver for almost half the episode, and his resignation to his defeat was really touching. Now on one final note, let's talk villains. First off, Huntress is a great villain (villainess?) Because it wasn't just the clichéd thing where Oliver realizes she's bad and just no longer cares about her. No, you can tell he still cares, and as Diggle points out, he would've killed her if she was anyone else. Now let's talk Merlyn and Slade. Merlyn was great because he was the behind the scenes manipulator combined with the evil reflection of the hero, and the actor just played him with the right level of smugness, that you really love to hate him. Slade was the type of villain who's super powerful and is out to tear Oliver's life apart because of the loss of the woman he loved. As I said earlier, he was played really well, and was very menacing. Between the two main villains, I would have to give Death-stroke the edge, because he was developed more, and just had more of an overall presence. So there you go, that's my take on Arrow, here's hoping the third season is just as good. ( by the way, I'll update this once I've finished watching season 3)

..ok.. just finished watching season one. Went in without any expectations... immediate impression after watching entire first season.. an episodic comic book with live action, with 'millionaires' no longer cuttin it.. gotta be 'billionaires.' Acting was very passable with some obvious exceptions.. overacting the main culprit (there's that comic book thing). Script was good most of the time, but the three story lines going on simultaneously was tiresome after awhile.. and the island portion got tedious and boring not too long into the season. Production values were impressive, considering the number of episodes in this season. This is like making twelve movies.. and considering that.. it must be said, they did it overall pretty well. The big exit in the last episode was somewhat a surprise, but in hindsight, they really could not have kept that threesome going back and forth any longer without being ridiculous. And as for right now.. who's actually dead or might still be alive... who cares? S2 will be interesting, I expect/ hope it will get better. As they show they know how to do it, and be that the case, if you're smart you learn from your lapses. So, now on to the next season! Sorry.. hard as I tried.. could not get through more than several episodes of season two. What this show really fails to do is come up with some bad guys that you really love to hate !! All good-evil shows have to have equal measures of both, and Arrow just doesn't do it. I'm gone. And as for rating.. S1 could maybe get a 7.. S2 is totally lacking, and deserves no more than a 5.

I am a comic book fan and this is definitely not supposed a  comic booky  show if you will. Firstly, the character of green arrow is not even called green arrow, so this tells you it is only loosely based off green arrow. Oliver Queen is more serious but he is still a well done character. The Arrow is unsurprisingly a more serious vigilante. He definitely becomes more of a hero rather than a vigilante which is a good change. The origin is a bit different but still very well done. The flashbacks get better as the show goes on. The plot escalates well. Most of the characters develop well especially Tommy, and detective Lance. I just don't like Laurel but the rest of the show makes up for it. Any who insult this show, likely haven't watched through even season 1, so they have no reason to complain. It was good from the beginning but improves as the show goes on. In closing, watch and see for yourself.

Something about playing DC Comics' billionaire crime-fighter character Oliver Queen turns Stephen Amell into a less than inspired actor. As in, he can't deliver most of his lines with any of the baseline conviction that either a billionaire or a super hero should have in abundance. Amell's decision to stay as far away from gravitas as possible saps energy from this show about a modern day Robin Hood meets Batman type of hero. Throw in bad guys who wait to be shot with an (eponymous) arrow rather than pull the trigger on their leveled and waiting bad guy guns, and lazy and ill-framed exterior shots reminiscent of a lackluster episode of CHiPs, and you get left with some mostly unwatchable television.

I haven't watched a series live since literally, the first few episodes of Boston Legal. My Gwife doesn't want me playing video games, and my life, at 40, is too exciting for Ashley Madison ;) and too boring for primetime, I have to do something.So in about a month I've watched way too many series. Repetitive themes, ailing heros, too predictable, abrupt plot changes, and not enough of an audience.To all that, this is the best show around.I've watched, and liked, Game of Thrones (I think the writers might only drink more than I do), Walking Dead (solid and S L O W), another of this genre Daredevil (see above repetitive themes, and although entertaining altogether Unbelievable), the Strain, House of Cards (politics is my favorite sport), and Falling Skies (I thought only a cat had 9 lives, but a better SciFi than most movies of late).You've got good actors, good writers, a solid story, and imaginative believability, unless you've never seen what money can do, buy.I fast forward through most TV series because they stuff the content with  fillers , not this one, best I've seen, from that stand point. Season 1 alone I can vouch for, but it's a really really goodie....

NOTE: SPOILERS AHEADWhen I first saw the trailer for this show, having been a big Justice League fan as a kid, I immediately (and erroneously) started looking forward to watching this show. Oliver Queen to me was always like an alternative to Batman with his sort of solo act, martial arts type persona, along with added humor. However, while this rendition of Oliver Queen has both the fitness and martial arts skills down, his portrayal of the character seems almost confused at times, as he seems to try too hard to be faking the playboy type guy that he once was, while also being a serious tough guy at other times. These almost bipolar type actions detract from the character, as one would only expect Oliver Queen to be able to naturally be able to play both roles rather than one or the other. Had this series been a little more realistic, then Oliver Queen would have been effectively giving himself away as a fake to anybody who spends more than 10 minutes around him. This however, I could forgive or perhaps live with until the character becomes more refined, however there is an even bigger problem that I have with this series....THE WRITING! When I watch this show, there are often cringe worthy one liners (often times followed by the characters walking away from the person they just supposedly  zinged ), and awkward pauses all along the way, which I guess the writers/producers may have thought evoked more emotion, but it is terribly overused and makes the series feel more like a Soap Opera than an action series. I mean seriously, most true to heart superhero action fans are not looking for a soap opera styled show with excessive drama, and the plot is already thick enough on its own that a dramatic pause after every big detail really is not necessary. Oliver Queen I really think if the writers/producer took a similar style to the now critically proclaimed Daredevil Netflix Original series, DC comic's Arrow really could be a true competitor.There are a few more issues that I could go on about, like the fact that every person who shoots an automatic weapons seems less capable of shooting something than a Stormtrooper from Star Wars. Or that it is not explained until at least very late into the 1st season (as that is as far as I got before having to call it quits) how Oliver Queen became a computer genius after being away for 5 years on a deserted island even though he is somehow able to program a computer virus to steal 40 million dollars in the first episode. Or the fact that Queen brought all sorts of top of the line bulky tech and workout equipment down to an abandoned warehouse when all he seems to drive in the first season is a motorcycle without all the homeless people outside the warehouse noticing him bringing the equipment in......I could go on, but it would be pointless. This series had some serious potential, and maybe it does get better after the first season. But I honestly couldn't bring myself to watch more of the Soap Opera style nonsense that this series seems to have been successful by. If you are really looking for a great, much better written superhero series at the moment, I strongly recommend Netflix's Daredevil. This series, Arrow, is not deserving of the 8.1 it now has on IMDb, as that rating was quite misleading to me. I seriously hope this series lives on, but through the eyes of different writers, because I really do like the story line and actors. Actors: 7/10Action: 6.5/10 (the guys missing Arrow in some sequences with fully auto weapons was cringe worthy)Plot: 7/10 (starting from episode 1, the plot has more holes at first than Swiss Cheese, but at least some get filled by 3/4 of the way through Season 1)Writing: 4/10Overall: 6/10

Following the theme of Nolan's gritty Dark Knight, we are given the TV show about Arrow, a billionaire playboy turned vigilante. You'd think that that's where the similarities would end, but it doesn't. Watching this TV show, I felt like I was watching a lazy rip off of the Dark Knight trilogy, except this time there is far too much soap operas, not enough moral dilemmas, and a lot or racy scenes to rope in newcomers.This show's iteration of Oliver Queen is broody, a master martial artist, and tactical genius - sound familiar? That's right, Queen here is not a gruff guy with a sense of humour, he's just broody. In fact, a major plot point in season 2 practically screams Batman.But Oliver Queen's live screen portrayal is not that bad. At one point or another, I had just wished they had killed off one of the main characters because it was just that unbearable. A lot of them felt very one dimensional, only gaining depth in the later half of season 2 - which is very late to flesh out characters. This is probably due to the cringe-worthy dialogue that even the best actors would have trouble making the audience believe the emotional weight behind it.Special effects and scale of the actions scenes are very lacking in size and scope as well as authenticity. The fighting looks extremely choreographed with long panning shots generally seen in Asian martial arts films, but the thing is, the actors in Arrow don't have a martial arts background which makes the long panning shots feel caricatured.All in all, the acting could be better if the directing was better. Dialogue needs a huge overhaul, and there is a lot of potential wasted when it comes to the story. So many times, the narrative could've been more powerful if the writers were willing to take a more daring risk instead of the clichéd deus ex wrap up.

First time I heard about Green Arrow / Oliver Queen was in Smallville. I loved this series and just at the moment Justin Hartley came to play Arrow, I was in love. The last two seasons I only watched because of him. And then there was the plan to make Arrow to a new series. The best news ever. But, there was this little problem, Justin was not the man, they wanna make the new Arrow. At first I was really angry because of that and I didn't wanna watch the new thing. But then I saw the trailer and I thought, OK, Stephen will get his chance to proof his talent. And what can I say ? He made it.Since the beginning I knew, why Justin never got this role. He is sweet and too cute to play this dark character they created for the new Arrow. Stephen is so good in his job and I do believe everything he say or do. Oh and Felicity, I love her. She is so funny and cute. The best friend you will every have. Also Diggle. This Guy is amazing. Oliver will never have a better friend than him.I loved the first and the second season. The third was not really my thing. There were a lot of stories I didn't liked. So I hope season 4 will be better again.

Arrow is a good series not as fictional as the flash or as exaggerated as batman or Superman.its a really tense series and you can't even stop yourself from spoiling it I didn't like season 3 too much because it was a bit too dramatic. OK - first off - it's clear from the overall rating that this series has a lot of fans - so just to weed out those who will unequivocally defend this series - let me clarify:What I'm looking for is responses form people who, maybe started optimistic - found their interest waning - but persevered, so they can tell me if they: -found that their perseverance was eventually rewarded, or -concluded that they'd wasted their time.This is a series I decided to give try - with no prior knowledge of it (Green Arrow was a DC hero I was aware of, but never read as a kid).Characters felt clunky - back story fairly average for a Superhero origin story - but enough to make me continue (it seemed like this would be a fairly entertaining, if not game changing bit of throwaway entertainment. Some seeds of longer term story lines sown - maybe it'll be OK. So I continuedFirst couple of episodes - if I had to do something I'd pause, go do my thing and return. But by about the third episode - I found I was no longer bothering to pause because it was unlikely I'd miss any critical scenes/moments. By episode 5 I started doing other things while watching it (I fancy a cup of tea. I think I'll get my dumbbells out and do my daily exercises. I need to pee) because it's that easy to follow without much attention.Much of the series seems to be populated by a seemingly endless stream of vignettes, where one character gives a short speech to Oliver before he exits the room silenced by their outburst, or they exit the room, leaving a speechless Oliver to either: -stoically reflect on what they said (and consequently hone/modify the ethics/morality of his behaviour) or -languish in the pain caused by trying to maintain a dual identity without upsetting/alienating his family friends and loved ones.It's gotten really tedious!There's nothing really new here. But that's fine. Characters are pretty dumb/simplistic. That's fine too. Problem is - there's little that's exciting here either (some fairly well choreographed fight scenes in places - but not many).Each episode: -We find out who he's targeting this week; -it's interspersed with aforementioned vignettes (where' he'll either learn or teach a valuable lesson; -there's some (seemingly) superfluous romance thrown in (like the 'will they won't they?' romance between his ex and his best mate - presumably that'll lead somewhere - but please get on with it - cuz I really don't care what take-out food they're cosying up to tonight!) -one or two flashback scenes, which loosely correlate to the morality of this week's bad guy story -get bad guy -onto the next episode.I think the problem for me is that there's not a single character or actor I've really warmed to (apart from maybe the cop/father) - nor is there a character I've really grown to despise. I find most of them just mildly irritating - or just plain dull.However, I recognise that some series don't find their stride immediately - just a some comic books didn't, until an imaginative writer came along. But if I haven't found something to hang some hope on after 6 episodes I start feeling like I'm being taken for a ride (e.g the pace of the series is deliberately pedestrian so as to elongate a thin storyline across as many lucrative ad breaks as possible)As I said: I'm now at episode 8 and about to give up, with a view to taking up knitting as a more thrilling distraction. But it's not to late for my mind to be changed ;)Many thanks.

I rated this 5 purely because of the really irritating amount of screen time they use with all the drama about who's loving who and who wants to be with who. I don't care and i'm sure any die hard Green Arrow fan couldn't care either. Why do so many producers insist in adding so much love drama in a series that could be 100% better without it. Yeah love interests are a real thing, but why does it seem the main focus in this series? is it to draw in a wider audience? your audience are people who are initially interested in the DC/comic book genre and i can bet a lot of them have lost interest because of your poor choices by making this seem like some stupid twilight series but with heroes and not vampires.Overall though i enjoy it but i just have to grit my teeth through the painful love drama, there is no need to make the show so focused in that area, WE WANT SUPER HEROES NOT LOVE STORYS!
